problem_text:
By a theorem of W. Burnside, if χ ∈ Irr(G) and χ(1) > 1, then there exists x ∈ G such that χ(x) = 0, that is, only the linear characters are “nonvanishing”. It is interesting to consider the dual notion of nonvanishing elements of a finite group G, that is, the elements x ∈ G such that χ(x) ̸= 0 for all χ ∈ Irr(G).

a) It is proved (I. M. Isaacs, G. Navarro, T. R. Wolf, J. Algebra, 222, no. 2 (1999), 413–423) that if G is solvable and x ∈ G is a nonvanishing element of odd order, then x belongs to the Fitting subgroup F(G). Is this true for elements of even order too? (M. Miyamoto showed in 2008 that every nontrivial abelian normal subgroup of a finite group contains a nonvanishing element.)

b) Which nonabelian simple groups have nonidentity nonvanishing elements? (For example, A7 has.)

I. M. Isaacs
